p.seg: “I have relied on making saddles for three generations to feed my family.
Now, if I move,
the people of the Song Kingdom who seek saddles will not know where to find me.
I will then have nothing to eat.
I hope the Prime Minister will be concerned about my inability to eat.”
For this reason,
I will not move.
The house to the west is tall,
and my house is low.
The floodwater flows through my house easily,
therefore I do not block it."
Shi Yin Chi returned to Jing,
and the King of Jing was just about to raise troops and attack Song.
Shi Yin Chi advised the King of Jing, saying:
"Song should not be attacked.
Its ruler is virtuous,
and its prime minister is benevolent.
The virtuous can win the people,
and the benevolent can employ men.
If the Jing Kingdom attacks it,
will it not be without success and be laughed at by the world?"
Therefore, he abandoned attacking Song and attacked Zheng instead.
Confucius heard of this and said:
"The one who cultivates matters in the temple and court, and settles disputes a thousand miles away,
is he not referring to Sicheng Zihan?"
Song was situated amongst three great states with ten thousand chariots each.
During Zihan's time,
there were no mutual invasions,
and the borders expanded in all four directions.
He assisted Duke Ping, Duke Yuan, and Duke Jing until the end of his life.
Was he not exceptionally benevolent and frugal?
Therefore, the merit of benevolence and frugality is great.
Thus, the Mingtang had a thatched roof and pillars of artemisia,
and earthen steps of three levels.
First Month of Spring, Part One
1.1 "Annals of the First Month of Spring"
It is said: In the first month of spring:
The sun is in Ying Shi (a constellation),
At dusk, Shen (Orion) is in the middle (of the sky),
At dawn, Wei (Scorpio) is in the middle.
Its days are Jia and Yi (the first two of the ten Heavenly Stems).
Its emperor is Tai Hao.
Its spirit is Gou Mang.
Its creatures are scaly.
Its musical note is Jiao.
The pitch pipe matches Tai Cu (a musical note).
Its number is eight.
Its taste is sour.
Its smell is goaty.
Its sacrifice is to the door.
The primary offering is the spleen.
The east wind thaws the ice.
Hibernating insects begin to stir and awaken.
Fish rise to the surface, carrying ice.
Otters sacrifice fish (place them on the bank as if offering them).
Geese wait to fly north.
The Son of Heaven dwells in the left apartment of the Green Yang Palace,
Rides in a carriage adorned with luan birds,
Drives a team of blue dragons,
Carries a green flag,
He wears clothes of green,
adorns himself with green jade,
and eats wheat and mutton.
His utensils are simple and well-ventilated.
In this month,
the Beginning of Spring occurs.
Three days before the Beginning of Spring,
the Grand Historian reports to the Son of Heaven, saying:
"On such-and-such day, the Beginning of Spring will occur;
the flourishing virtue resides in wood."
The Son of Heaven then fasts.
On the day of the Beginning of Spring,
the Son of Heaven personally leads the three highest ministers, the nine ministers, the feudal lords, and the grand officers to greet Spring in the eastern suburbs.
Upon returning,
he rewards the ministers, feudal lords, and grand officers in the court.
He commands the prime minister to spread virtue and harmonize ordinances,
to perform celebrations and bestow favor,
extending down to the common people.
The celebratory gifts are then distributed,
with none being inappropriately given.
He then commands the Grand Historian
to uphold the classics and observe the law,
to oversee the movements of the sun, moon, and stars,
to ensure the constellations are in their proper positions without error,
to not lose track of the established order,
and to maintain the beginnings as constant.
In this month,
the Son of Heaven then, on the first day, prays to God for a good harvest.
He then chooses an auspicious day.
The Son of Heaven personally loads the plow and hoe,
placing them between the shield and the armored attendant who drives the chariot.
He leads the three dukes, nine ministers, feudal lords, and grand officers to personally cultivate the imperial field.
The Son of Heaven pushes the plow three times,
the three dukes five times,
and the ministers, feudal lords, and grand officers nine times.
Returning,
he holds a wine cup in the Great Chamber.
The three dukes, nine ministers, feudal lords, and grand officers all serve him food,
and this is called "rewarding wine."
In this month,
the heavenly energy descends,
and the earthly energy ascends.
Heaven and earth are in harmony,
and plants and trees flourish and move.
The king announces agricultural affairs:
He orders the stewards of the fields in the eastern suburbs
to all repair the boundaries of the fields,
carefully examine the paths and roads,
and skillfully assess the hills, slopes, dangerous places, plains, and wetlands,
what is suitable for the land,
and what grains should be planted,
in order to teach and guide the people.
He must personally attend to these matters.
With agricultural affairs already put in order,
first establish standard prices,
then farmers will not be confused.
In this month,
order the music master to enter and practice dance.
Then refine the sacrificial ceremonies,
order sacrifices to mountains, forests, rivers, and marshes,
sacrificial animals should not be female.
Prohibit the felling of trees,
do not overturn nests,
do not kill baby insects, pregnant dogs, young animals, or fledglings,
do not take fawns or eggs,
do not gather large crowds,
do not build city walls,
bury bones and conceal corpses.
In this month,
it is not permissible to initiate warfare,
if warfare is initiated, there will certainly be heavenly calamity.
The initiation of war
cannot begin from me.
Do not alter the Way of Heaven,
do not sever the principles of Earth,
do not disrupt the order of Humanity.
If, in the first month of spring, the ordinances of summer are carried out,
then winds and rain will be unseasonal,
When the grasses and trees wither from drought,
the state then has cause for fear.
If the commands of autumn are carried out in spring,
then its people will suffer a great plague,
violent winds and torrential rains will frequently arrive together,
and goosefoot and wormwood will flourish.
If the commands of winter are carried out in spring,
then floods will cause ruin,
frost and snow will be severe,
and the first planting will fail.
1.2 *Bensheng* (Root of Life)
Secondly: That which gives rise to all things is
Heaven and Earth;
that which nurtures them is
Man.
The one who can nurture what Heaven has produced without harming it is called the Son of Heaven.
The actions of the Son of Heaven
are for the sake of preserving all of Heaven.
This is the reason why officials are established.
The establishment of officials is for the sake of preserving life.
The deluded rulers of the present age
appoint many officials but instead harm life,
thus losing the reason for establishing them.
It is like repairing weapons
to prepare for bandits;
if one repairs weapons but instead uses them to attack oneself,
then one also loses what one is trying to cultivate.
Now, the nature of water is clear,
but earth stirs it up,
and therefore it cannot be clear.
The nature of man is longevity,
but things (external objects) erode it,
and therefore one cannot attain longevity.
Things are
what we use to nourish our nature,
not what we use our nature to nourish.
People in the world today,
those who are deluded mostly use their nature to nourish things,
and thus do not understand what is light and heavy (important and unimportant).
If one does not understand what is light and heavy,
then the heavy becomes light,
and the light becomes heavy.
If this is so,
then every action will fail.
To use this way as a ruler is perverse,
to use it as a subject is chaotic,
to use it as a son is mad.
If a state has even one of these three,
there is no hope, it will surely perish.
Now, if there is a sound here,
the ear will certainly be pleased to hear it,
but if one hears it constantly, it will make one deaf,
He certainly will not listen.
If there is a color here,
the eye seeing it will certainly be satisfied,
but having seen it, it causes blindness,
he certainly will not look at it.
If there is a flavor here,
the mouth eating it will certainly be satisfied,
but having eaten it, it causes dumbness,
he certainly will not eat it.
Therefore, the sage in regards to sounds, colors, and flavors,
if it benefits his nature, he takes it,
if it harms his nature, he abandons it;
this is the way to preserve his nature.
Those who are wealthy and noble in the world,
are mostly deluded by sounds, colors, and flavors;
they seek them day and night,
and if they are fortunate enough to obtain them, they run away from them.
Running away,
how can their nature not be harmed?
Ten thousand people wielding bows shoot together
at one target,
and every shot hits the target.
The myriad things are clearly arrayed,
to harm one's life,
and no life is not harmed;
to benefit one's life,
and no life is not lengthened.
Therefore, the sage regulates the myriad things,
in order to complete their natural endowment.
When one's natural endowment is complete, then their spirit will be harmonious,
their eyes will be clear,
their ears will be sharp,
their nose will be sensitive to smells,
their mouth will be quick,
and all three hundred and sixty joints will be unobstructed and smooth.
Such a person as this:
speaks not, yet is trusted;
plans not, yet hits the mark;
considers not, yet attains;
their essence penetrates Heaven and Earth,
their spirit covers the universe;
there is nothing among things that they do not receive,
nothing that they do not encompass,
like Heaven and Earth themselves;
when above, they are a Son of Heaven and not arrogant,
when below, they are a commoner and not confused;
this is what is meant by a person of complete virtue.
To be noble and rich and yet not know the Dao,
is only enough to cause trouble,
it is better to be poor and lowly.
For the poor and lowly, obtaining things is difficult,
even if they wanted to exceed their means, how could they?
When going out, they use carriages,
when entering, they use sedan chairs,
striving for self-indulgence,
This is called the mechanism of decline and ruin.
Rich meats and strong wines,
used to strengthen oneself,
are called food that rots the intestines.
Delicate beauty, fair teeth,
the music of Zheng and Wei,
used to delight oneself,
are called axes that chop away at one's nature.
These three calamities
are brought about by wealth and nobility.
Therefore, in ancient times, there were those who were unwilling to be wealthy and noble,
because they valued life,
not to boast of a name,
but for its true value.
Therefore, this argument is something that must be carefully examined.
1.3 "Valuing Oneself"
The third says: Chui was supremely skilled.
People do not cherish Chui's fingers,
but cherish their own fingers,
because they are beneficial to them.
People do not cherish the jade of Mount Kun or the pearls of the rivers Jiang and Han,
but cherish their own single dark-blue jade disk or small pearl,
because they are beneficial to them.
Now, my life belongs to me,
and the benefit to me is very great.
Considering its value,
to be ennobled as the Son of Heaven is not enough to compare to it;
Considering its importance,
even possessing the wealth of the world cannot exchange for it.
Considering its safety and danger,
losing it in a single dawn,
you'll never recover it in your whole life.
These three things,
are what those who possess the Dao are careful about.
However, some are careful about it but end up harming it instead,
because they do not understand the true nature of life and destiny.
If you do not understand the true nature of life and destiny,
what is the benefit of being careful?
It's like a teacher who loves their student,
but cannot help but pillow them with chaff;
it's like a deaf person raising an infant,
peeking at it in the hall during a thunderclap;
there is no difference from someone who doesn't know how to be careful.
Those who do not know how to be careful,
for them, life and death, existence and destruction, what is permissible and what is not,
have never had any distinction.
For those who have never had any distinction,
what they call right is never right,
what they call wrong is never wrong,
they call right what is actually wrong,
and call wrong what is actually right.
This is called extreme confusion.
A person like this,
is cursed by Heaven.
Using this to govern oneself,
Surely death and calamity;
using this to govern a state,
surely ruin and destruction.
Now, death, calamity, ruin, and destruction
do not come of themselves,
confusion summons them.
Longevity, attainment, and the constant are also like this.
Therefore, one who has the Dao
does not examine what is summoned,
but examines that which summons it,
then their arrival cannot be prevented.
This argument is one that must be carefully considered.
To make Wu Huo forcefully pull a bull's tail,
the tail breaks and the strength is exhausted,
yet the bull cannot be made to move,
is contrary.
To have a five-foot-tall child lead it by its nose ring,
and the bull goes wherever it is led, is compliant.
The lords and nobles of the world,
whether wise or foolish,
all desire long life and prolonged vision,
yet daily act contrary to their own lives;
what good is desiring it?
In general, the lengthening of life
comes from compliance with it;
that which makes life non-compliant
is desire;
Therefore, the sage must first moderate desires.
If a room is large, it has too much yin;
if a platform is high, it has too much yang.
Too much yin causes collapse;
too much yang causes weakness.
This is the trouble of yin and yang not being in harmony.
Therefore, the former kings did not live in large rooms,
did not build high platforms,
did not taste many delicacies,
and did not wear excessively warm clothing.
Excessively warm clothing causes the skin pores to become blocked;
when the pores are blocked, qi cannot flow through.
Tasting many delicacies causes the stomach to become full;
when the stomach is full, the center becomes greatly distended.
If the center is greatly distended and qi cannot flow through,
can longevity be attained through this?
In the past, the former sage kings, in creating parks and gardens,
only made them sufficient for observing the scenery and exercising the body.
In creating palaces and pavilions,
they only made them sufficient for avoiding dryness and dampness.
In creating carriages, horses, clothing, and furs,
they only made them sufficient for relaxing the body and warming the bones.
In creating food, drink, and sweet wine,
they only made them sufficient for satisfying the taste and filling emptiness.
In creating sounds, colors, and music,
they only made them sufficient for pacifying the nature and entertaining themselves.
These five things
The reason why the sagely kings cultivated their nature
was not because they favored thrift and detested extravagance,
but because they regulated according to their nature.
1.4 "Valuing the Public"
Fourthly,
in the past, when the former sagely kings governed the world,
they invariably prioritized the public interest.
When the public interest is prioritized, the world is at peace.
Peace is attained through prioritizing the public.
If we examine past records,
there have been many who have gained the world;
they inevitably gained it through prioritizing the public,
and they inevitably lost it through being partial.
Generally, the establishment of a ruler
arises from the public interest.
Therefore, the "Great Plan" says:
"Without bias, without partisanship,
the royal way is level and broad;
without prejudice, without inclination,
follow the righteousness of the king;
without acting on personal preference,
follow the Way of the king;
without acting on personal dislike,
follow the Path of the king."
The world is not the world of one person;
The world belongs to all under Heaven.
The harmony of yin and yang
does not favor the growth of a single type (of thing).
Sweet dew and timely rain
do not benefit one thing alone.
The lord of the myriad people
does not favor a single person.
When Bo Qin was about to depart,
he asked about how to govern Lu.
The Duke of Zhou said:
"Benefit them, but do not seek benefit (for yourself)."
A man of Chu lost his bow
and was unwilling to search for it,
saying:
"A man of Chu lost it,
and a man of Chu will find it;
why search for it?"
Confucius heard of it and said:
"It would be better to remove the 'Chu'."
Lao Dan heard of it and said:
"It would be better to remove the 'man'."
Therefore, Lao Dan was the most impartial.
Heaven and Earth are great;
they give birth but do not treat as children;
they accomplish but do not possess.
The myriad things are all benefited by their bounty and receive their advantages,
yet none know where it originates.
This is the virtue of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors.
When Guan Zhong was ill,
Duke Huan went to inquire about him,
and said:
"Father Zhong is ill,
his condition is serious,
the people of the state do not conceal it,
to whom shall I entrust the state?"
Guan Zhong replied,
"In the past, I exhausted my strength and wisdom,
yet I was still not sufficient to know him.
Now my illness is occurring within the space of morning and evening,
how can I speak?"
Duke Huan said,
"This is a major matter,
I wish Father Zhong to instruct me."
Guan Zhong respectfully agreed,
and said,
"Whom does Your Grace wish to appoint as Prime Minister?"
The Duke said,
"Would Bao Shuya be suitable?"
Guan Zhong replied,
"He would not be suitable.
Yi Wu is well-acquainted with Bao Shuya,
Bao Shuya's character is
pure, incorruptible, and upright.
He does not associate with those who are not like himself,
he does not compare himself to others,
"Once he hears of someone's fault,
he never forgets it in his whole life."
"If it must be,
then how about Xi Peng?"
"As for Xi Peng's character,
he aims high but seeks from below;
he shames those not as good as the Yellow Emperor,
and pities those not as good as himself.
With regard to the country,
there are things he does not hear;
with regard to things,
there are things he does not know;
with regard to people,
there are things he does not see.
If it must be,
then Xi Peng is acceptable."
A prime minister
is a great official.
One who holds a great office
should not desire petty observations,
nor should he desire petty wisdom.
Therefore, it is said:
"A great carpenter does not whittle,
a great cook does not arrange the pickles,
a great warrior does not brawl,
a great army does not pillage."
Duke Huan acted justly and eliminated personal grudges,
employing Guan Zhong and becoming the leader of the Five Hegemons.
To act privately and favor those one loves,
and to employ Shu Diao while insects emerge from the house (a sign of decay).
When people are young, they are foolish,
when they grow old, they are wise.
Therefore, being wise and using it for private gain
is not as good as being foolish and using it for the public good.
To be drunk every day and adorn oneself with fine clothes,
to establish public good for private gain,
to be greedy and violent and seek to become king:
even Shun could not do that.
1.5 "Removing Selfishness"
Chapter Five:
Heaven covers without partiality,
Earth carries without partiality,
the sun and moon shine without partiality,
the four seasons move without partiality,
They practice their virtue, and all things are able to grow and flourish.
The Yellow Emperor said:
"Sounds should be restrained,
colors should be restrained,
clothing should be restrained,
fragrances should be restrained,
flavors should be restrained,
dwellings should be restrained."
Yao had ten sons,
but he did not give the throne to his son, instead he bestowed it upon Shun.
Shun had nine sons,
but he did not give the throne to his son, instead he bestowed it upon Yu.
This is ultimate impartiality.
Duke Ping of Jin asked Qi Huangyang,
"Nanyang lacks a magistrate.
Who is suitable to fill the position?"
Qi Huangyang replied,
"Xie Hu is suitable."
Duke Ping said,
"Isn't Xie Hu your enemy?"
He replied,
"Your Lordship asked about suitability,
not about my enemy."
Duke Ping said,
"Good."
Thereupon, he employed him.
The people of the state praised it as good.
After some time,
Duke Ping again asked Qi Huangyang,
"The state lacks a military officer.
Who is suitable to fill the position?"
He replied,
"Wu is suitable."
Duke Ping said,
"Isn't Wu the son of Zi?"
He replied,
"The ruler asks what is permissible;
he does not ask about the son of his minister."
Duke Ping said,
"Good."
And then he employed him.
The people of the state praised it as good.
Confucius heard of it and said,
"Excellent!
The words of Qi Huangyang!
In external recommendations, he does not avoid his enemy;
in internal recommendations, he does not avoid his son."
Qi Huangyang can be called impartial.
There was a Grand Master of the Mohists, Fu,
who lived in Qin.
His son killed someone.
King Hui of Qin said,
"Sir, you are old,
and have no other son.
I have already ordered the officials not to execute him.
I hope you will listen to me in this matter."
Fu replied,
"The law of the Mohists states:
'He who kills shall die;
he who injures shall be punished.'
This is how we prohibit killing and injuring.
Now, prohibiting the killing and injuring of people
is a great principle of the world.
Even if the king were to grant amnesty for it,
and order the officials not to punish
the perpetrator, Fu Tun would certainly not be able to avoid enacting the laws of the Mohists."
He did not allow King Hui's request
and consequently had him killed.
A son is one's personal affection,
to endure going against personal affection in order to carry out a great principle,
the Grand Master can be called impartial.
A cook prepares and seasons food but does not dare to eat it himself,
therefore, he can be a cook.
If the cook were to prepare and season food and eat it himself,
then he could not be a cook.
The rulers who become kings and hegemons are also like this,
they punish the violent without being biased,
and use the land to enfeoff the worthy men of the world,
therefore, they can become kings and hegemons.
If a king or hegemon were to punish the violent but keep the gains for himself,
then he also could not become a king or hegemon.
The Second Chapter: Mid-Spring
2.1 *Zhong Chun Ji* (Annals of Mid-Spring)
In the month of mid-spring:
the sun is in Kui,
at dusk, the bow star is in the middle,
At dawn the Jian star is in the middle.
The days are Jia and Yi.
Its emperor is Tai Hao.
Its spirit is Gou Mang.
Its insect is the scaled (kind).
Its musical note is Jiao (角).
The musical pipe corresponds to Jia Zhong (夾鐘).
Its number is eight.
Its taste is sour.
Its smell is rank.
Its sacrifice is at the door.
The primary offering is the spleen.
Rainwater begins.
Peach and plum trees blossom.
The oriole sings.
The hawk transforms into a dove.
The Son of Heaven dwells in the Azure Yang Grand Temple,
riding in a Luan chariot,
drawn by azure dragons,
bearing an azure flag,
wearing azure clothes,
adorned with azure jade,
eating wheat and mutton,
its vessels are sparse and permeable.
In this month,
secure sprouts,
nourish the young and small,
Provide for the orphans.
Choose an auspicious day.
Order the people to establish communal shrines.
Order the officials
to inspect the prisons,
remove the cangues and fetters,
to not engage in unrestrained plunder,
and to cease lawsuits.
In this month,
the dark bird (swallow) arrives.
On the day of its arrival,
sacrifice a complete ox to Gao Mei (the high mediatrix of marriage).
The Son of Heaven personally goes,
and the queen with her nine concubines and attendants,
then performs the ritual of the Son of Heaven's personal chariot,
adorning it with a bow case and quiver,
and bestowing it with a bow and arrows before Gao Mei.
In this month,
day and night are equal.
Thunder then begins to sound,
and lightning first flashes.
Dormant creatures all stir,
opening their burrows and beginning to emerge.
Three days before the thunder,
shake the bell to announce to the multitudes, saying:
"Thunder will soon sound,
If there are those who do not regulate their appearance and demeanor,
they will bear imperfect children,
and surely have misfortune and disaster."
At the equinox,
standardize weights and measures,
equalize balances and stones,
correct measuring containers,
and rectify the accuracy of measures.
In this month,
farmers should rest a little,
and repair doors and windows,
making sure ancestral temples are prepared.
Do not undertake major projects,
so as not to hinder agricultural work.
In this month,
do not drain rivers and marshes,
do not dredge ponds and pools,
do not burn mountains and forests.
The Son of Heaven then presents a lamb to open the ice,
first offering it in the ancestral temple.
On the first *ding* day,
the Music Master is ordered to enter the school and perform dances;
the Son of Heaven then leads the three dukes, nine ministers, and feudal lords to personally observe them.
On the second *ding* day,
the Music Master is again ordered to enter and practice music.
In this month,
sacrifices are made without sacrificial animals,
using jade tablets and jade disks,
and exchanging hides and currency.
If in the second month of spring, the commands of autumn are carried out,
then the country will have great floods,
cold air will arrive completely,
and bandits and enemies will come to attack.
If the commands of winter are carried out,
then the yang energy will not prevail,
and the wheat will not ripen,
and the people will plunder each other.
If the commands of summer are carried out,
then the country will have a great drought,
warm air will arrive early,
and insects and borers will cause harm.
2.2 "Valuing Life"
Secondly,
the sage deeply considers the world,
and nothing is more valuable than life.
The ears, eyes, nose, and mouth
are servants of life.
Although the ears desire sound,
and the eyes desire color,
and the nose desires fragrance,
Although the mouth desires delicacies,
it stops if they are harmful to life.
Those in charge of the four orifices,
do not do what is not beneficial to life.
From this, we can see that
the ears, eyes, nose, and mouth,
cannot act independently,
but must be controlled.
It is like an official position,
one cannot act arbitrarily,
but must be controlled.
This is the art of valuing life.
Yao offered the empire to Zizhou Zhifu.
Zizhou Zhifu replied:
"It would be acceptable for me to be the Son of Heaven.
However, I recently have a hidden, worrying disease,
and I am about to treat it,
I have no time to be in charge of the empire."
The empire is a heavy burden,
yet he would not harm his life with it,
how much more so with other things?
Only one who would not harm his life with the empire,
can be entrusted with the empire.
In Yue, the ruler was killed by three generations of his people.
Prince Sou was troubled by this
and fled to the Dan Cave.
The state of Yue had no ruler.
They sought Prince Sou but could not find him.
They followed him to the Dan Cave.
Prince Sou refused to come out.
The people of Yue smoked him out with mugwort
and transported him in the royal carriage.
Prince Sou grasped the carriage rail and boarded the carriage,
looked up to the sky and cried out,
"O Ruler,
could you not just leave me alone!"
It was not that Prince Sou disliked being a ruler,
but he disliked the troubles of being a ruler.
A man like Prince Sou
can be said to not harm his life for the sake of the state.
This is precisely what the people of Yue desired, to have him as their ruler.
The ruler of Lu heard that Yan He was a man who had attained the Dao,
and sent someone with gifts to offer him.
Yan He was guarding the gate,
wearing clothes of coarse cloth,
and personally feeding the oxen.
The messenger from the ruler of Lu arrived,
and Yan He personally received him.
The messenger said,
"Is this the house of Yan He?"
Yan He replied,
"This is He's house."
The messenger presented the gifts.
Yan He replied,
"I fear that listening to a misunderstanding will bring blame upon the messenger;
it would be better to investigate it thoroughly."
The messenger returned, conducted a thorough investigation,
and came back to seek him again,
and then he could not avoid it.
Therefore, someone like Yan He
does not dislike wealth and high position;
it is because he values life more that he dislikes them.
The rulers of the world
mostly use wealth and high position to treat those who have attained the Way with arrogance.
How sad it is that they do not understand each other!
Therefore, it is said:
The essence of the Way
is for maintaining one's own person;
its remnants
are for managing the state;
and its dregs
are for governing the world.
From this perspective,
the achievements of emperors and kings
are the leftover business of sages;
they are not the way to perfect oneself and nurture life.
Today, the gentlemen of the world
mostly endanger themselves and abandon their lives in pursuit of external things.
What can they possibly achieve with this?
What does he intend to do with this?
In all the actions of a sage,
one must examine the reason for them and the purpose for which they are done.
Now, suppose there is a person here
who uses the pearl of Marquis Sui to shoot at a thousand-fathom bird.
The world will surely laugh at him.
Why is that?
What is used is valuable,
while what is sought is insignificant.
Is life not even more valuable than the pearl of Marquis Sui?
Master Zihua said:
"To preserve life completely is the highest,
to diminish life is next,
to die is next,
to force life is the lowest."
Therefore, what is called respecting life
refers to preserving life completely.
What is called preserving life completely
is that all six desires obtain what is appropriate for them.
What is called diminishing life
is that the six desires partially obtain what is appropriate for them.
Diminishing life means that what is esteemed is thinned.
The greater the diminution,
the thinner the esteem.
What is called death
is having no means of knowing,
returning to the state before birth.
The so-called "forced living"
means that the six desires cannot attain their proper satisfaction,
and all obtain what they greatly loathe:
being subjected,
being humiliated.
No humiliation is greater than injustice.
Therefore, injustice
is "forced living."
And "forced living" is not limited to injustice.
Therefore, it is said that "forced living" is not as good as death.
How do we know this is so?
Hearing what is loathsome
is not as good as hearing nothing;
seeing what is loathsome
is not as good as seeing nothing.
Therefore, people cover their ears during thunder,
and cover their eyes during lightning.
This is an analogy.
If all those with the six desires
know what they greatly loathe
and inevitably cannot escape it,
it is better to have no means of knowing.
Having no means of knowing
is what we call death.
Therefore, "forced living" is not as good as death.
One who loves meat
does not mean a rotten rat.
A lover of wine,
does not mean one who ruins wine;
one who values life,
does not mean one who forces life.
2.3 *Emotions and Desires*
It is said:
Heaven gives birth to people and causes them to have greed and desire.
Desire has emotion,
emotion has limits.
The sage cultivates limits to stop desire,
therefore, he does not overstep acting on his emotions.
Thus, the ear desires the five sounds,
the eye desires the five colors,
the mouth desires the five flavors;
this is emotion.
These three things,
whether noble or base, foolish or wise, virtuous or unworthy, they desire them all alike;
even Shen Nong and the Yellow Emperor are the same as Jie and Zhou in this.
The reason why sages are different
is that they obtain their emotions.
If one is moved by valuing life, then one obtains one's emotions;
if one is not moved by valuing life, then one loses one's emotions.
These two things
are the foundation of life and death, survival and ruin.
Common rulers harm their emotions,
Therefore, every action leads to ruin and defeat.
The ears cannot be satiated,
the eyes cannot be satisfied,
the mouth cannot be filled,
the body is entirely full of growths (swellings),
the sinews and bones become heavy and stagnant,
the blood vessels become blocked and congested,
the nine orifices are empty and desolate,
and actions lose their appropriateness.
Even with a Peng Zu-like lifespan,
one still cannot remedy it.
With regard to things,
what is unattainable is desired,
what is insatiable is sought,
greatly losing the basis of life.
The people resent and slander,
and great enmities are created.
Temper is easily roused,
haughty and unstable,
vaunting power and loving cleverness,
the breast filled with deceit and fraud,
neglecting virtue and righteousness,
and hurrying after wicked gain.
The body becomes burdened and impoverished,
even if one later regrets it,
what help will there be then?
Cunning flattery is near,
while upright integrity is far.
When the state is in great peril,
and one regrets past mistakes,
it is still impossible to reverse the situation.
Hearing words and being startled,
one cannot understand the reason.
All kinds of ailments arise angrily,
and chaotic difficulties arrive frequently.
Using this to govern the people,
it becomes a great worry for oneself.
The ears do not delight in sounds,
the eyes do not delight in sights,
the mouth does not savor flavors,
there is no difference from death.
The ancients who attained the Dao,
lived long lives,
and were able to enjoy sounds, sights, and tastes
for a long time.
Why is this so?
Because their principles were established early.
If principles are established early, then one knows to be frugal early.
If one knows to be frugal early, then one's essence will not be exhausted.
If autumn is cold early, then winter will surely be warm.
If spring has much rain, then summer will surely be dry.
Heaven and earth cannot have both,
how much more so for humankind?
Humans are the same as heaven and earth.
Although the forms of the myriad things are different,
Their nature is fundamentally one.
Therefore, the ancients who governed themselves and the world
necessarily emulated Heaven and Earth.
If a respected wine-pourer serves many, the wine will quickly be exhausted.
The things from which great nobility draws are many,
therefore, the life of great nobility is often quickly exhausted.
It is not merely that the myriad things draw from them;
they also diminish their own lives to provide for the people of the world,
and in the end, they are unaware of it themselves.
Though their achievements are realized externally,
their lives are depleted internally.
Their ears cannot hear,
their eyes cannot see,
their mouths cannot eat,
their chests are greatly disturbed,
they speak wildly and conjure up visions,
on the verge of death,
they are disoriented, startled, and fearful,
not knowing what to do.
To use one's mind in this way,
is it not lamentable!
The people of the world who serve their rulers
all regard Sun Shu'ao's encounter with King Zhuang of Jing as fortunate.
But those with understanding of the Way view it differently;
this was the good fortune of the Jing kingdom.
King Zhuang of Jing loved to travel and hunt,
galloping about shooting birds and beasts,
Enjoyment knew no bounds;
All the toils within the state and the worries of the feudal lords were transferred to Sun Shuao.
Sun Shuao toiled day and night without rest,
Not even taking his own well-being into consideration.
Therefore, he enabled King Zhuang's achievements to be recorded on bamboo and silk,
And passed down to later generations.
2.4 *On Dyeing*
It is said:
Mozi saw someone dyeing plain silk
and sighed, saying:
"Dyed in blue, it becomes blue;
Dyed in yellow, it becomes yellow.
What enters (the dye) changes it,
And its color also changes.
After being dyed five times, it is considered to have five colors."
Therefore, one must be careful about dyeing.
It is not only so with dyeing silk,
States also have their dyeing.
Shun was dyed by Xu You and Boyang,
Yu was dyed by Gaotao and Boyi,
Tang was dyed by Yi Yin and Zhong Hui,
King Wu was dyed by Grand Duke Wang and Duke of Zhou.
These four kings were dyed correctly,
Therefore, they ruled the world,
And were established as Sons of Heaven.
Fame and gain obscure heaven and earth,
and throughout the world, when righteousness is shown, people invariably mention these four kings.
Xia Jie was influenced by Gan Xin and Qi Zhong Rong,
Yin Zhou was influenced by Chong Hou and E Lai,
Zhou Liwang was influenced by Guo Gong Changfu and Rong Yizhong,
Youwang was influenced by Guo Gong Gu and Ji Gong Dun.
These four kings were improperly influenced,
therefore their states were ruined and their bodies died,
and they became the laughingstock of the world.
Throughout the world, when unrighteousness is used to shame people, these four kings are invariably mentioned.
Duke Huan of Qi was influenced by Guan Zhong and Bao Shu,
Duke Wen of Jin was influenced by Jiu Fan and Xie Yan,
King Zhuang of Jing was influenced by Sun Shu Ao and Shen Yin Zheng,
King Helu of Wu was influenced by Wu Yuan and Wen Zhi Yi,
King Goujian of Yue was influenced by Fan Li and Da Fu Zhong.
These five lords were properly influenced,
therefore they dominated the feudal lords,
and their fame and achievements were passed down to later generations.
Fan Jishi was influenced by Zhang Liushuo and Wang Sheng,
Zhongxing Yin was influenced by Huang Jiqin and Gao Jiang,
King Fucha of Wu was influenced by Wangsun Xiong and Tai Zai Pi,
Zhi Boyao was influenced by Zhi Guo and Zhang Wu,
Lord Shang of Zhongshan was influenced by Wei Yi and Yan Chang,
King Kang of Song was influenced by Tang Yang and Tian Bu Yin.
These six lords were improperly influenced,
therefore their states were all ruined and perished,
their bodies either died disgracefully,
their ancestral temples received no blood sacrifices,
Cutting off their posterity,
causing the separation of ruler and ministers,
and the wandering of the people,
so that when the world spoke of greed and cruelty, people invariably cited these six rulers.
To be a ruler is not for the sake of personal glory,
nor is it for the sake of personal comfort,
but to uphold principle.
Upholding principle arises from proper influences.
Therefore, those who were good at being rulers in ancient times
labored in selecting people
but were at ease in official matters,
having grasped the essential principle.
Those who are incapable of being rulers
injure their bodies and waste their minds,
worrying their hearts and tiring their eyes and ears,
the country becomes more endangered,
and they themselves become more disgraced,
because they do not understand the essential cause.
If they do not understand the essential cause, then their influences are improper.
If their influences are improper,
how can principle ever be achieved?
The six rulers are examples of this.
These six rulers
did not fail to value their countries and cherish their lives,
but their influences were improper.
Thus, the reasons for survival and demise are not unique,
but also apply to emperors and kings.
It is not only the state that is influenced.
Confucius studied under Lao Dan, Meng Sukui, and Jing Shu.
Duke Hui of Lu sent the steward Rang to request the rites of suburban and ancestral temples from the Son of Heaven.
King Huan (Ping) sent the scribe Jiao to go.
Duke Hui stopped him.
Afterwards, the rites remained in Lu.
Mozi learned them.
These two gentlemen,
had no rank to make them known,
and no rewards to benefit people,
yet all those who praise prominent and glorious men in the world must mention these two gentlemen.
They have both been dead for a long time,
but their followers are increasingly numerous,
and their disciples increasingly abundant,
filling the world.
Kings, dukes, and great men follow and praise them.
Those who love their sons and younger brothers follow and learn from them.
There is never a time when it is cut off.
Zigong, Zixia, and Zengzi studied under Confucius.
Tian Zifang studied under Zigong.
Duan Ganmu studied under Zixia.
Wu Qi studied under Zengzi.
Qin Huali studied under Mozi.
Xu Fan studied under Qin Huali.
Tian Xi studied under Xu Fan.
The disciples and followers of Confucius and Mozi who have become prominent and glorious in the world are many,
too numerous to count.
All because what they were influenced by was proper.
2.5 *Gongming* (Merit and Fame)
Fifthly:
If one follows the correct path,
merit and fame cannot be escaped.
If you put fermented yellow maggots in a jar,
gathering them will produce sourness.
Trying to wash them away with water will certainly not work.
Using a wildcat to catch mice,
or using ice to attract flies,
even a skilled person cannot do.
Using rotten fish to drive away flies
only makes the flies come more, and you cannot stop them.
You must use the method of attracting them to get rid of them.
Jie and Zhou used the methods of driving people away to attract them.
Even if punishments are heavy and laws are strict, what good will it do?
When great cold arrives,
warming the people is beneficial;
when great heat is above,
the people will run towards coolness.
Therefore, the people have no fixed place;
they gather where they see benefit,
and leave where there is none.
If you wish to be the Son of Heaven,
observe where the people are running,
you must observe carefully.
In the world today,
it is extremely cold,
it is extremely hot,
yet the people have nowhere to run,
because what you take is equal to what you give.
If you wish to be the Son of Heaven,
Therefore, what is shown to the people
must necessarily be different.
If the conduct is not different,
even if the chaos is doubled from today,
the people will still have nowhere to flee.
If the people have nowhere to flee,
then the true king will be deposed,
the tyrant will be fortunate,
and the people will be in utter despair.
Therefore, in the present age,
if there are benevolent people,
they must attend to this matter;
if there is a wise ruler, he must attend to this matter.
The worthy and unworthy must be distinguished,
as immutable as fate,
as unchangeable as beauty and ugliness.
Jie and Zhou, though noble as the Son of Heaven and rich with the possessions of the world,
were able to completely harm the people of the world,
but could not gain a reputation for worthiness.
Guan Longfeng and Prince Bigan were able to risk death by decapitation
to argue against the faults of their superiors,
but could not share the reputation for worthiness with them.
Reputation truly cannot be shared;
it must come from its principle.
Ji Chun Ji, Third

First, it is said:
In the month of the last spring:
the sun is in Wei (the Stomach constellation),
at dusk, the Seven Stars constellation is at its meridian,
at dawn, the Qianniu (Oxherd) constellation is at its meridian.
The days are Jia and Yi (wood days).
The emperor is Taihao.
The spirit is Gou Mang.
The creature is scaled (fish, reptiles).
The note is Jiao (E).
The pitch-pipe corresponds to Gu Xi.
The number is eight.
The taste is sour.
The smell is rancid.
The sacrifice is to the door.
The offering is the spleen of the victim.
The paulownia tree begins to flower.
The field mouse transforms into a quail.
The rainbow first appears.
Duckweed begins to grow.

rides in a carriage adorned with phoenix bells,
is drawn by green dragons,
carries a green banner,
wears green robes,

He eats wheat and mutton.
His vessels are sparse and permeable.
In this month,
the Son of Heaven presents hemp garments to the former emperor.
He orders the boat officer to overturn boats,
overturning them five times and righting them five times.

traps and nets,

the Superintendent of the Fields is instructed
not to cut down mulberry or zhe trees.

the queen and consorts fast and purify themselves,

In this month,
the master craftsmen are instructed,
ordering all artisans,
to examine the measures of the five storehouses.
If in the last month of spring, winter commands are implemented,
then cold air will arise periodically,
grass and trees will all wither,
and the nation will experience great fear.
If summer commands are implemented,
then the people will suffer from many diseases and epidemics,
timely rain will not fall,
and the mountains and hills will not yield their bounty.
If autumn commands are implemented,
then the sky will be mostly overcast,
excessive rain will fall early,
and weapons and armor will rise up together (war will break out).
3.2 《Exhaustive Numbers》
Secondly, Heaven gives rise to Yin and Yang, cold and heat, dryness and dampness,
the transformations of the four seasons,
and the changes of all things,
none of which are without benefit,
none of which are without harm.
The sage observes the suitability of Yin and Yang,
discerns the benefits of all things in order to facilitate life,
therefore the spirit is at peace within the body,
and lifespan is able to be extended.
Extension of life does not mean shortening it and then prolonging it,
but rather completing its allotted span.
The task of completing one's allotted span
lies in eliminating harm.
What is meant by "removing harm"?
Excessive sweetness, excessive sourness, excessive bitterness, excessive spiciness, excessive saltiness—
when these five fill the body, harm arises.
Excessive joy, excessive anger, excessive worry, excessive fear, excessive sorrow—
when these five affect the spirit, harm arises.
Excessive cold, excessive heat, excessive dryness, excessive dampness, excessive wind,
excessive rain, excessive fog—
when these seven agitate the essence, harm arises.
Therefore, in all matters of nourishing life,
nothing is better than knowing the root.
If you know the root, then illness will have no way to arrive.
The gathering of essence and qi must have a way in.
If it gathers in feathered birds, it causes them to fly aloft;
if it gathers in running beasts, it causes them to move swiftly;
if it gathers in pearls and jade, it causes them to be pure and bright;
if it gathers in trees, it causes them to grow lushly;
if it gathers in sages, it causes them to be exceedingly enlightened.
As for the coming of essence and qi,
guide it by lightness and cause it to rise,
guide it by movement and cause it to flow,
guide it by beauty and cause it to become good,
guide it by growth and cause it to be nourished,
guide it by wisdom and cause it to become clear.
Flowing water does not rot,
a door hinge does not become riddled with ants—this is because of movement.
The same is true of the form and qi.
If the form (body) does not move, then the essence (精) does not flow.
If the essence does not flow, then the Qi becomes stagnant.
If stagnant in the head, it results in swelling or wind (headaches, etc.).
If stagnant in the ears, it results in deafness or hearing loss (挶 could mean "stiff").
If stagnant in the eyes, it results in blurred vision or blindness.
If stagnant in the nose, it results in rhinitis (runny nose) or nasal congestion.
If stagnant in the abdomen, it results in distension or accumulations (府 means "storehouse" but refers to accumulation here).
If stagnant in the feet, it results in weakness or paralysis.
Places with light water produce many bald people and goiter sufferers.
Places with heavy water produce many swollen-legged people (尰) and cripples (躄).
Places with sweet water produce many people with good looks and beautiful people.
Places with spicy water produce many boils/abscesses (疽) and acne sufferers (痤).
Places with bitter water produce many people with stunted growth (尪) and hunchbacks (傴).
In general, eating should not be forced or excessive.
In flavor, do not use strong flavors or heavy wines.
This is what is called "bringing illness to the head."
If one eats according to the proper times,
the body will surely be free of calamities.
In general, the proper way to eat is,
neither hungry nor full.
This is called "protecting the five viscera."
The mouth must savor flavors,
harmonize the essence and regulate demeanor,
guide it with spirit and Qi.
The joints should rejoice,
and together receive Qi.
When drinking, one must sip slowly,
and be upright and without perversity.
Now, in the world, people divine, practice divination, and offer prayers to deities;
therefore, their illnesses only increase.
It is like an archer;
if he shoots and does not hit the target,
to instead focus on adjusting the target stand,
what benefit is that to hitting the target?
Moreover, using hot water to stop boiling,
only makes the boiling increase;
removing the fire will stop it.
Therefore, shamans, doctors, and poisonous drugs
are employed to expel and cure,
so the people of old despised them,
because they address the symptoms, not the root cause.
3.3 "Prioritize Oneself"
It is said: Tang asked Yi Yin,
"How does one desire to take the world?"
Yi Yin answered,
"Desiring to take the world,
the world cannot be taken.
If it *can* be taken,
your person will be taken first."
The root of all matters
must first be the cultivation of oneself,
Treasure that great treasure.
Use the new,
discard the old,
and the skin pores will be unblocked.
Vital essence and energy will be renewed daily,
evil influences will be completely removed,
and one will live out one's natural lifespan.
This is what is meant by a true person.
In the past, the wise sage kings,
perfected themselves, and the world was perfected;
governed themselves, and the world was governed.
Therefore, one skilled in echoing does not seek echoes in sound;
one skilled in casting shadows does not seek shadows in form;
one who governs the world does not seek the world but seeks oneself.
The *Book of Poetry* says: "The virtuous gentleman,
his deportment is without error.
His deportment is without error,
and thus he rectifies the four kingdoms,"
meaning he rectifies himself.
Therefore, return to the Dao, and the self will be good;
practice righteousness, and others will be good;
fully prepare music and ceremonies befitting a ruler,
and the hundred officials will already be governed,
and the myriad people will already be benefited.
The completion of these three things
lies in non-action (wuwei).
The Way of non-action is called conquering Heaven;
Righteousness says benefit the self,
the ruler says disregard the self.
Disregarding the self leads to attentive listening,
benefiting the self leads to peace and quiet.
Overcoming Heaven leads to obeying nature.
Obeying nature results in keen intelligence and longevity,
peace and quiet results in advancing one's career and finding pleasure in one's hometown.
Attentive listening results in blocking treachery and preventing panic.
Therefore, if the ruler above loses his way, then the border is invaded by the enemy;
if internal conduct is lost,
then reputation falls to the outside.
Therefore, a hundred-fathom pine tree,
if its roots are injured below,
then its top withers above;
the states of Shang and Zhou,
if plans are lost in the mind,
then commands are troubled over there.
Therefore, if the mind is obtained, then listening is obtained;
if listening is obtained, then affairs are obtained;
if affairs are obtained, then merit and fame are obtained.
The Five Emperors prioritized the Way and then virtue,
therefore their virtue was unsurpassed;
the Three Kings prioritized instruction and then execution,
therefore their affairs were unsurpassed in accomplishment;
the Five Hegemons prioritized affairs and then military force,
therefore their military force was unsurpassed in strength.
In the present age,
clever plans proceed together,
Deceitful tactics are used in succession,
attacks and battles do not cease,
the number of countries destroyed and lords humiliated increases,
what is being pursued are trivial matters.
Xia Hou Xiang fought with the Youhu clan at Ganze and did not win.
The six ministers requested to attack again.
Xia Hou Xiang said:
"No.
Our territory is not small,
our people are not few,
to fight and not win
is because my virtue is thin and my teaching is not good."
Therefore, he did not use double mats when resting,
he did not eat two flavors of food,
the zither and lute were not strung,
the bells and drums were not repaired,
his children were not adorned,
he treated relatives as relatives and elders as elders,
he respected the worthy and employed the able,
and within a year the Youhu clan submitted.
Therefore, those who wish to overcome others must first overcome themselves,
those who wish to judge others must first judge themselves,
those who wish to know others must first know themselves.
The *Book of Poetry* says: "Holding the reins as if arranging silk threads."
Confucius said:
"If one understands this saying, one can govern the world."
Zigong said,
"How hasty he is!"
Confucius said,
"It's not that he is hasty,
but that what he does here,
becomes manifest as accomplishments there.
The sage cultivates and adorns himself,
and that becomes manifest as accomplishments throughout the world."
Therefore, Zihua Zi said,
"When hills and mounds are formed, those who dwell in caves are secure;
when great waters and deep pools are formed, fish and turtles are secure;
when pine and cypress trees are fully grown, those traveling on the road find shade."
Confucius met with Duke Ai of Lu.
Duke Ai said,
"Someone told me,
'For one who governs a state,
governing is done merely in the hall above.'
I consider this to be roundabout and impractical talk."
Confucius said,
"This is not impractical talk.
I have heard it said: 'What one gains in oneself, one gains from others;
what one loses in oneself, one loses from others.'
He who governs the world without going out of his door,
is surely one who knows to reflect upon himself!"
3.4 *Discussing People*
Fourthly: The way of the ruler is concise,
the ruler guards what is near.
The highest [ruler] turns back to examine himself;
the next best seeks [faults] in others.
The more distant he seeks [the cause of problems],
the more estranged his relationship with [the people] becomes.
The more forcefully he seeks [to control],
the further he strays from what is right.
What does it mean to "turn back to examine himself"?
It means moderating the pleasures of the eyes and ears,
restraining desires,
abandoning clever schemes,
discarding cunning practices,
and letting the mind wander in the realm of the infinite,
guiding the heart along the path of nature.
If one does this, then nothing can harm his Heaven-endowed nature.
If nothing harms his Heaven-endowed nature, then his wisdom becomes refined.
If his wisdom becomes refined, then he understands the divine.
To understand the divine is called "obtaining the One."
All those myriad forms [in the universe],
are formed after obtaining the One.
Therefore, if one knows [how to] know the One,
then he can respond to things with change,
be broad, great, profound, and deep,
and cannot be fathomed.
His virtuous conduct will shine brilliantly,
comparable to the sun and moon,
and cannot be extinguished.
Heroes will esteem him,
Distant guests who arrive,
cannot be blocked.
Their intentions and spirits are freely expressed,
without any constraints,
they cannot be shepherded or controlled.
Therefore, understanding and knowing Oneness,
leads to returning to simplicity;
desires and cravings are easily satisfied,
taking and nurturing are frugal and moderate,
and thus such a person is unattainable (by manipulation).
Separated from the world, finding joy in oneself,
one's inner feelings are pure and white,
and thus immeasurable.
Authority and power cannot frighten them,
severity and strictness cannot instill fear,
and thus they cannot be subdued.
Therefore, understanding and knowing Oneness,
allows one to act and move in accordance with present duties,
to interact and adapt with the times,
without limit or exhaustion.
Actions and movements are based on calculation,
taking and giving follow principle,
and thus they cannot be deceived.
Words leave nothing unsaid,
they gather in the very flesh and skin,
and thus cannot be altered or refuted.
Slanderers are trapped in poverty and distress,
the virtuous consequently flourish and rise,
It cannot be concealed.
Therefore, understanding one thing
is like understanding Heaven and Earth.
Then, what task cannot be overcome,
what thing cannot be responded to?
It is like a charioteer
who turns inward to himself.
Then the chariot is light and the horses swift,
reaching far distances, returning, feeding, and not tiring.
In the past, the ruined rulers of the ancient world
considered faults to lie with others.
Therefore, they killed and executed people daily without ceasing,
until they perished without realizing it.
The rising kings of the Three Dynasties
considered faults to lie with themselves.
Therefore, they achieved daily accomplishments without decline,
until they achieved kingship.
What does it mean to seek from others?
People are of the same kind, yet their wisdom differs.
The worthy and the unworthy are different.
All use clever words and persuasive arguments
to defend themselves.
This is how unworthy rulers cause chaos.
In general, when evaluating a person,
if he is universally recognized, observe what he respects.
If he is noble, observe whom he promotes.
If he is wealthy, observe how he provides.
If he is listened to, observe his actions.
If he is inactive, observe his preferences.
If he is accustomed to something, observe his words.
If he is impoverished, observe what he does not accept.
If he is base, observe what he does not do.
Test his integrity by pleasing him.

4.4 The "Slandering Disciples"
Fourthly: It is the teaching of an accomplished teacher

then the paths of wickedness and perversion are blocked,
and the arts of reason and righteousness prevail.
If these six qualities are not attained through learning,
then the ruler cannot command his subjects,
the father cannot command his son,

It is human nature

If doing something is painful,

Reflecting on human nature
reveals how to encourage learning.

5.3 Extravagant Music
It is said: People all sustain their lives by living,
but they do not know the reason they live.
People all know through their knowledge,
but they do not know the reason they know.
Knowing the reason one knows is called understanding the Dao;
not knowing the reason one knows is called discarding treasure.
Those who discard treasure will certainly suffer misfortune.
The rulers of the world
mostly consider pearls, jade, halberds, and swords to be treasures.
The more treasures they have, the more resentful the people become;
the more endangered the country becomes;
the more precarious their personal situation becomes;
thus, they lose the true meaning of treasure.
The music of a chaotic age is similar to this.
When the sounds of wood and leather are like thunder,
when the sounds of metal and stone are like lightning,
when the sounds of stringed instruments, flutes, singing, and dancing are like clamor,
it may be possible to startle the mind,
move the ears and eyes,

Its strange and monstrous occurrences:

Book of Mid-Autumn, Seventh
7.1 "Book of Mid-Autumn"
It is said:
In the month of Mid-Autumn:
the summer solstice is forty-six days past.
The sun is in Wing,
at dusk, the Dipper is in the middle,
at dawn, the Hyades are in the middle.
Then comes the Beginning of Autumn. Its days are Geng and Xin.
Its emperor is Shaohao.
Its god is Rushou.
Its creature is the furry animal.
Its musical note is Shang.
The musical pipe corresponds to Yi Ze.
Its number is nine.
Its flavor is pungent.
Its smell is rancid.
Its sacrifice is to the door.

Cool winds arrive.
White dew descends.
Cold cicadas chirp.
Eagles then sacrifice birds.
It is the beginning of employing and executing punishments.
The Son of Heaven resides in the left pavilion of the Zongzhang Hall,
rides the war chariot, yokes white camels,
carries a white banner,
wears white clothing,
adorns himself with white jade,
eats hemp seeds and dog.
Its vessels are simple and deep.
In this month,
the Beginning of Autumn occurs.
Three days before the Beginning of Autumn,
the Grand Historian informs the Son of Heaven,
saying:

the Son of Heaven personally leads the Three Dukes, Nine Ministers, feudal lords, and grand officers to greet the autumn in the western suburbs.

he then rewards the military leaders and warriors at court.

to select soldiers, sharpen weapons,
and examine the outstanding talents;
to exclusively appoint those with merit,

to investigate and execute the tyrannical and disrespectful,

and to patrol those distant lands.
In this month,
he orders the officials
to revise laws and regulations,
to repair prisons,
to prepare fetters and handcuffs,
to prohibit villainy,
to be careful of crimes and evil,
and to focus on capturing offenders.
He orders those who administer justice
to examine injuries and investigate wounds,
to inspect fractures and judge with precision;
to settle lawsuits
Must be upright and impartial;
Execute the guilty,
Strictly determine punishments.
Heaven and earth begin to become stern,

In this month,
Farmers then bring up the grain.
The Son of Heaven tastes the new grain,
First presenting it to the ancestral temple.
He commands the officials
to begin the harvest and storage.
Complete the embankments,
Carefully secure the blockages,
To prepare for floods and heavy rains.
Repair palaces and houses,
Repair the walls and fences,
Mend the city walls.
In this month,
Do not enfeoff lords or establish high officials, do not cede land,
Bestow heavy gifts, or send out great envoys.
If one carries out these orders,
Then the cool wind will arrive in thirty days.
If in early autumn one carries out winter commands,
Then the yin energy will greatly overcome,
Armored insects will ruin the grain,
Then the soldiers of the Rong people came.
If we enact the ordinances of spring,
then their country will suffer drought.
The yang energy will return,
and the five grains will not ripen.
If we enact the ordinances of summer,
then there will be many fires.
Cold and heat will be out of balance,

7.2 "Controlling Soldiers"
Secondly,
the ancient sage kings had righteous armies but never had armies that were put to rest (completely abolished).
The origin of armies is ancient;
it exists together with the beginning of the people.
Generally speaking, the army
is power (威);
and power
is strength (力).
The people's possession of power and strength is in their nature.
This nature is what is received from Heaven,
and is not something that humans can create.
The martial cannot change it,
and the artisan cannot move it.
The origin of armies is ancient.
Huangdi and Yandi already used water and fire.
Gonggong shi already repeatedly created difficulties.
The Five Emperors already fought with each other.
Dynasties rise and fall,
the victor takes control.
It is also said, "Chiyou created weapons,"
but Chiyou did not create weapons;
he merely improved upon them.
Before the time of Chiyou,
the people already stripped forests for wood to fight with, and the victor became the leader.
The leader was still insufficient to govern them,
so they established a lord.
The lord was still insufficient to govern them,
so they established a Son of Heaven.
The establishment of the Son of Heaven came from the lord,
the establishment of the lord came from the leader,
and the establishment of the leader came from conflict.
The source of conflict and fighting has been around for a long time,
it cannot be prohibited,
it cannot be stopped.
Therefore, the sage kings of old had righteous armies but never ceased warfare.
If a household has no angry scolding,
then the faults of young children will immediately be seen;
if a state has no punishments,
then the people's acts of mutual aggression will immediately be seen;
if the world has no punitive expeditions,
then the princes' acts of mutual violence will immediately be seen.
Therefore, angry scolding cannot be abolished in the household,
punishments cannot be abolished in the state,
punitive expeditions cannot be abolished in the world;
It is simply a matter of skill and clumsiness.
Therefore, the sage kings of old had righteous armies but never abolished armies.
To want to prohibit all food in the world because someone died from overeating
is absurd;
to want to prohibit all boats in the world because someone died while riding a boat
is absurd;
to want to abolish all weapons in the world because someone lost their state through the use of weapons
is absurd.
That weapons cannot be abolished
is like water and fire:
if used well, they bring good fortune;
if used poorly, they bring disaster.
It is the same with those who use medicine well:
if they obtain good medicine, they save people;
if they obtain bad medicine, they kill people.
Righteous armies are like good medicine for the world, and their importance is great indeed.
Moreover, the origin of weapons goes back far;
there has never been a moment when they were not used.
Noble and base, old and young, wise and foolish all share in them;
there is only a difference between the great and the small.
Observe the minute aspects of warfare:
Intent held in the heart but not yet expressed is
warfare;
a fierce look is warfare;
a change of countenance is warfare;
arrogant speech is warfare;
drawing someone near or pushing someone away is warfare;
repeated betrayal is warfare;
extravagant competition is warfare;
the three armies attacking and battling is warfare.
These eight are all warfare,
whether the contention be small or large.
Those in the present age who speak hastily of putting down arms,
use warfare their entire lives without realizing it, which is absurd.
Therefore, though their arguments are strong,
though their discussions are eloquent,
though their literary knowledge is vast,
they still are not listened to.
Therefore, the ancient sage kings had righteous warfare
but none who put down arms.
If warfare is truly righteous,
used to punish tyrannical rulers and uplift suffering people,
the people's joy at it
is like a filial son seeing a loving parent,
like a hungry person seeing delicious food;
the people's shouting and rushing toward it
is like a powerful crossbow shot into a deep ravine,
like accumulating great water and losing its containing dike.
Even a mediocre ruler would still be able to possess his people,
How much more so is this true of a tyrannical ruler?
7.3 *Quelling Disorder*
Third,
the present age
is extremely corrupt,
and the suffering of the common people
cannot be increased any further.
The Son of Heaven is already cut off (from power),
virtuous men are discarded and hidden,
the rulers of the world act as they please,
separating themselves from the people,
and the common people have nowhere to turn to for redress.
If there are wise rulers and outstanding scholars in the world,
they should carefully examine this argument,
then their armies will be armies of righteousness.
The people of the world
will be like those who are about to die and yet live,
like those who are about to be disgraced and yet be honored,
like those who are about to suffer and yet be at ease.
If the rulers of the world act as they please,
then even men of average character will flee their rulers and abandon their relatives,
how much more so will those who are worthless?
Therefore, when an army of righteousness arrives,
the ruler of the world will be unable to hold onto his people,
and relatives will be unable to restrain their sons.
In general, being a leader of the people of the world,
there is no greater consideration than promoting those who possess the Way and suppressing those who are without the Way,
Reward what is righteous, and punish what is unrighteous.
In the present age,
scholars mostly disapprove of military attacks.
If one disapproves of military attacks, yet advocates for defense,

then if one advocates for defense, the methods that local leaders call "promoting the moral and curbing the immoral," and "rewarding the righteous and punishing the unrighteous" cannot be put into practice.
The benefits and harms to those who govern the people of the world
depend on carefully examining this argument.
Military attacks and defense are essentially the same thing,
yet people differ in what they choose to accept or reject.
They use persuasive arguments to dismiss it,
and ultimately arrive at no definitive conclusion.
This is surely due to not understanding,
which is foolish;
or understanding but deceiving one's heart,
which is fraudulent.
For those who are fraudulent and foolish,
even if they argue, it is useless.
They deem wrong what should be accepted, and accept what should be deemed wrong.
This is benefiting what should be harmed,
and securing what should be endangered.
Such arguments, if they are considered profound,
become the greatest cause of trouble for the world, and bring the greatest harm to the common people.
Therefore, those who have the benefit of the people of the world at heart
cannot but thoroughly examine this argument.
Now, in the matter of military attacks,
there has never been a case where the immoral were not attacked and the unrighteous were not punished.
To attack the immoral and punish the unrighteous
Then there would be no greater fortune,
and the common people would reap no greater benefit.
To prohibit it
is to suppress the way of virtue and attack the cause of righteousness; it is to bring to ruin the achievements of Tang and Wu and perpetuate the errors of Jie and Zhou.
The reason why people detest being without virtue and unrighteous
is because of the punishment it brings;
the reason why they aspire to be virtuous and act righteously
is because of the reward it brings.
Now, if being without virtue and unrighteousness persists,
and those who are so are rewarded,
while being virtuous and acting righteously are driven to ruin,
and those who are so are punished,
rewarding evil and punishing good,
and yet desiring the people to be well-governed,
is that not difficult?
Therefore, those who throw the world into chaos and harm the common people
are best discussed as being great.
7.4 "Blocking Up"
Fourthly:
As for the mindset of defending and guarding,
there has never been a case of not defending the way of no virtue and guarding the way of unrighteousness.
To defend the way of no virtue and guard the way of unrighteousness
is the greatest misfortune,
and the deepest harm to the people of the world.
In general, in defense and guarding,
the highest approach is through persuasion,
Next comes the use of arms.
If persuasion results in widespread acceptance and adherence,
one should contemplate it day and night,
meticulously devoting oneself to the task.
When awake, one should recite it;
when asleep, one should dream of it.
One should exert oneself to the point of parching the lips and drying the lungs,
exhausting the mind and wounding the spirit.
One should cite the achievements of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors to please the ruler,
and mention the strategies of the Five Hegemons and famous figures to lend credence to the matter.
One should attend court early and leave late,
reporting to the one who plans the military action
and spreading the message to the masses to clarify the principles.
If, after all efforts, the persuasion remains isolated and ineffective,
then one must inevitably resort to arms.
Resorting to arms
inevitably leads to conflict and strife.
The nature of conflict and strife
invariably involves killing.
This amounts to killing innocent people to support those who are without principle and unjust.
For the unprincipled and unjust to prevail
is to foster harm and suppress benefit to the world.
Even if one were to fortunately achieve victory,
calamity would only begin to grow.
The law of the former kings states:
"Reward those who do good,
punish those who do evil."
This is the ancient way,
Cannot be changed.
Now, to not distinguish between what is right and what is wrong,
and hastily resort to seizing, attacking, defending,
there is no greater unrighteousness,
and there is nothing that harms the people of the world more severely.
Therefore, seizing and attacking cannot
be condemned,
attacking and seizing cannot
be undertaken,
defending and guarding cannot
be condemned,
defending and guarding cannot
be undertaken;
only righteous warfare is permissible.
If warfare is righteous,
attacking and seizing are also permissible,
and defending and guarding are also permissible.
If warfare is unrighteous,
attacking and seizing are not permissible,
and defending and guarding are not permissible.
That Xia Jie and Yin Zhou were unprincipled to such an extent
was due to luck;
that Wu Fucha and Zhi Boyao invaded and plundered to such an extent
was due to luck;
that Jin Li, Chen Ling, and Song Kang were wicked to such an extent
was due to luck.
If Jie and Zhou knew that they would certainly lose their kingdoms, die,
and have their lineage exterminated without any descendants,
I did not know that tyranny and lack of principle could reach such a degree.
King Fuchai of Wu and Zhi Bo Yao knew that their states would surely be reduced to ruins,
and their persons subjected to punishment and execution.
I did not know that their wickedness, lack of principle, encroachment, and plunder could reach such a degree.
Duke Li of Jin knew that he would surely die at the hands of the artisan Li Shi,
Duke Ling of Chen knew that he would surely die at the hands of Xia Zhengshu,
and Duke Kang of Song knew that he would surely die in Wen. I did not know that their wickedness could reach such a degree.
These seven rulers,
were exceedingly unprincipled and unjust:
the number of innocent people they slaughtered
cannot be counted in the tens of thousands.
The deaths of the strong, the young, the old, and even unborn fetuses,
filled the broad plains.
They piled (corpses) high in deep valleys and great ravines,
flung them into great rivers,
accumulated ashes (of cremated bodies),
filled ditches and dangerous places,
faced flying arrows,
trod on naked blades,
and added to this the suffering of freezing, starvation, hunger, and cold.
Even in this present age,
it is becoming even worse.
Therefore, the exposed bones are countless,
forming mounds like hills and mountains.
If there is an enlightened ruler or benevolent man in the world,
who deeply contemplates this,
it is enough to cause him pain,
it is enough to cause him grief.
Observe where this originates.
It originates from the abandonment of those who possess the Way
and the unrestrained actions of those who lack the Way.
The unrestrained actions of those who lack the Way
are fortunate indeed!
Therefore, the trouble in the world
lies not in rescue and defense,
but in the good fortune of the unworthy.
When the argument for rescue and defense emerges,
the unworthy become even more fortunate,
and the worthy become even more doubtful.
Therefore, what greatly disorders the world lies in hastily adopting rescue and defense without considering their righteousness.
7.5 "Cherishing Favor"
Fifthly:
Generally speaking, the explanations of gentlemen
are not merely for the sake of argument;
the deliberations of scholars
are not merely for the sake of talk.
They must hit the mark of reason before explaining,
and must be appropriate to righteousness before deliberating.
Therefore, if righteousness is explained, rulers and great men will increasingly love reason, and the common people will increasingly practice righteousness.
When the Way of righteousness and reason is made clear,
the methods of tyranny, deceit, and usurpation will cease.
Tyranny and deceit are opposed to righteousness and reason;
their power cannot both prevail,
they cannot coexist.
Therefore, when the army enters the enemy's territory,
the people know where to seek protection,
and the common people know they will not die.
Reaching the outskirts of towns and cities,
do not harm the five grains,
do not dig up graves,
do not cut down trees,
do not burn stockpiles,
do not burn houses,
do not seize domestic animals.
If you capture people, treat them well and send them back,
in order to show good and evil;
keep faith with the people,

in order to seize the enemy's resources. If, after all this, there are still those who harbor resentment, brave danger, continue in their errors, and refuse to listen, then even resorting to force is permissible.
First, make a proclamation and issue a declaration, saying:
"The army comes
to save the people from death.
Your ruler on high is without virtue,
arrogant, haughty, neglectful, and lazy,
greedy, violent, and cruel to the masses,
self-willed and arbitrary,
rejecting the ways of the sages,
despising and reviling the former kings,
rejecting and slandering the old laws,
not obeying Heaven above,
not benefiting the people below,
levying taxes without end,
To demand without satiety,
to unjustly kill the innocent,
to reward and punish improperly.
Those who act like this
are those whom Heaven will punish,
those whom the people will hate,
and are not fit to be rulers.
Now, the coming of our army
is to punish those who are not fit to be rulers,
to eliminate the people's hatred, and to follow the Way of Heaven.
If there are people who oppose the Way of Heaven and protect the enemies of the people,
they will be killed and their families exterminated without pardon.
Those who can listen with their families
will be rewarded with the possessions of a family;
those who listen with their neighborhoods
will be rewarded with the possessions of a neighborhood;
those who listen with their villages
will be rewarded with the possessions of a village;
those who listen with their towns
will be rewarded with the possessions of a town;
those who listen with their state
will be rewarded with the possessions of a state."
Therefore, when we conquer a state, we will not harm its people,
but will only punish those who deserve to be punished.
We will promote its outstanding scholars and enfeoff them as marquises,
select its virtuous and worthy men and honor and elevate them,
seek out its orphans and widows and provide relief for them,
and show respect and courtesy to its elders.
All were increased in their stipends,
and raised in their rank.
They judged their criminals and rescued them;
they divided the gold of the treasuries,
and distributed the grain of the granaries,
in order to pacify and soothe the masses,
not keeping the wealth for themselves;
they inquired about the populous local shrines and large ancestral temples,
and restored those that the people did not want abolished,
adding extensively to their sacrificial rites.
Therefore, the virtuous glorified their names,
the elders rejoiced in their rites,
and the people cherished their virtue.
Now, if there were a person here
who could bring a single person back from the dead,
then the world would certainly vie to serve him.
The righteous army revives more than just one person,
so who would not rejoice?
Therefore, when the righteous army arrives,
the people of neighboring states flock to it like flowing water,
and the people of the conquered state look to it as if it were their parents.
The farther they travel,
the more people they gain;
without a blade being crossed, the people submit as if transformed.
The Records of Mid-Autumn, Eighth Month

First, it is said:

the sun is in the constellation Horn (角),
at dusk the Herdboy (牽牛) is in the middle (of the sky),

Its taste is pungent.
Its smell is rank.

Offer the liver first in sacrifice.
Cool winds arise.
Migratory geese arrive.
Dark swallows return (south).
The birds store up provisions.
The Son of Heaven resides in the Zongzhang Grand Temple (總章太廟),
rides in the war chariot,
is drawn by white camels,
carries the white banner,
wears white clothes,
wears white jade,
eats hemp seeds and dog meat.

This month,
nourish the aged and feeble,
bestow stools and canes,
and provide millet gruel and other food and drink.
